_header: By doughty Arthurs daws / That held England in good laws
Note:
For a version in couplets see 5002; see also 1144; for sixteenth-century versions see Wells (1916)
XWells, John Edwin. Manual of the Writings in Middle English, 1050-1400. New Haven, CT: Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences, 1916, 133-4.
_description: Launfal Miles, or Sir Launfal, a ‘Breton lai’ by Thomas Chestre — 1044 lines in 12-line stanzas

BlCottCalAII.First Lines:
Be douȝty Artours dawesÞat held engelond yn good
                    lawes…
BlCottCalAII.Last Lines: …Ȝeue vs alle hys blessyngAnd hys modyr marye
BlCottCalAII.Note: Ends ‘Amen’ at end of last line.
BlCottCalAII.Attributed Title:
Launfal miles (by scribe in upper margin, f. 35v); Launfall (as
                    RT on verso leaves thereafter); Explicit launfal (by scribe in lower margin, f.
                        42va); Another old poeme intitled Launfall (f. 1,
                    sixteenth-century list of contents)
